The Impact
The Immigration Institute of the Bay Area is a non-profit organization that provides high-quality, low-cost immigration legal services to the Bay Area community. 
They help immigrants to America stay in this country legally and become American citizens. Their locations offer services in English, Spanish, Mandarin, Dari, Hindi, and Urdu.
Last year, they did:

7000 office visits
3000 attendees at Workshops & Trainings
450 VAWA self-petitions / U-Visas
300 Naturalizations
250 Adjustment of Status
250 Work Authorizations
200 Consular Processings
200 Replacements / Renewals of Green Cards
100 Temporary Protective Status applications

They also help with:

applications for Citizenship and Naturalization
Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) applications, an Obama administration policy which protects illegal immigrants from deportation
family reunification services, including Lawful Permanent Residence applications for family members, green card applications, and Fiancé(e) visas
humanitarian services, for domestic violence and crime survivors, Temporary Protected Status (TPS) applicants, and asylees & refugees
free English as a Second Language (ESL) classes that emphasize speaking and cover United States government, history, and civics, all topics tested during the naturalization interview

Here's a full list of their services. Services are provided on a sliding scale based on income. Additionally, the group is largely managed and operated by people of color.
You should also donate to them directly!

 
Risks & Challenges
To maximize the proceeds we can pass on to the IIBA, I'm self-publishing and distributing the book! That'll mean that I'll have to figure out things like how to print a lot of copies and how to ship them out, so it may take me a bit longer to get things to you.
Other than that, the book is done and you can download it right now to print at home! 
 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute, no problem! The PDF is free, so please download it and color it at home. 
In return, I ask two things:
1) register to vote (takes 10 min online)! Even if you don't like any of the presidential candidates, 88% of all seats in Congress are up for election this year — 469 in total — and they're the ones who make the laws. Your vote matters!
2) to speak out against hateful speech whenever you encounter it in your community, even if the people being hated on look nothing like you, and even if it's awkward. We'll come together only if we understand each other first.
Otherwise, you can spend some time volunteering at an organization in your community which helps folks who may not feel so American right now.

story:
Fractal Rock is the recipient of a Burning Man Honorarium Arts grant and is brought to you by math geeks who love to build things and climb things. We hope that you interact with this piece at Burning Man this year, and can viscerally experience our math-based sculpture.


When Fractal Rock is on the playa, it will appear as an ossified helical structure that seems to glow from within. We want it to appear as if it is grown from the earth, an organic structure designed using math and built to scale through the love and labor of people who are inspired by its intriguing shape and mathematical foundations.


We want you to be able to walk up to the piece, where there will be a description of its philosophy, and then climb it. We hope that you’ll chat with the others who gather in Fractal Rock’s inner cavities and stare out at the goings-on and passers-by of the playa from atop your mathematical perch.

Fractal Rock will be finished in white fiberglass, and the texture of the surface will be similar to the texture of rock climbing holds, making it fun and easy to climb!

Fractal Rock was designed using fractals.

The following video is a good 2-minute explanation of fractals and how to generate a simple one.

In practice, fractals can be incredibly complicated and incredibly beautiful due to the ingenuity of the humans who mess around with them! We were inspired by the beauty of fractals, and the Julia set in particular. Our shape is a new perspective on fractal art. We used several Julia set fractals we liked and used software to mathematically interpolate (i.e. connect) these different patterns in three dimensions, so that we could build a 3D shape.

We hope that our piece inspires wonder in all those who interact with it, both at Burning Man and wherever we install it after the event. We especially hope that we can inspire people to be interested in creating their own math, art, or both.



Pooja Shah
Hi there! My name is Pooja. I went to Burning Man for the first time last year, and that experience, coupled with my own explorations of fractals and making, inspired me to give Fractal Rock a real shot! I'm a first-time playa artist and am excited to make this happen.

(Amazed by art at Burning Man 2015)


Stijn van der Linden, aka Virtox

Say hi to Stijn! :)

Stijn is an artist who started his career as an electrical engineer. He's the innovator behind the idea of using Julia set fractals to create mesmerizing 3D shapes. He's got quite a following within the 3D printing community, and his Julia set vases that he's published on Thingiverse are some of the most beautiful things I've ever seen. Here's a link to Virtox's Thingiverse gallery.

Here are some pictures of other works by Virtox. Beautiful, right?


Nigel Fluharty
Nigel is an Oakland-based artist, sculptor, and lighting specialist! Nigel is on our core fabrication team and will be the steel mastermind behind fabrication.
Levon Fox
Levon is another wonderful Oakland-based artist and sculptor who is formally trained as an architect. Levon is the brains behind how we should divvy up our shape into bite-sized steel pieces that we will weld together to create the flowing curves that are Fractal Rock.
A Gray
A is a fiberglass specialist who is going to help us finish Fractal Rock to its beautiful white rocky texture and ensure that our lighting is epic and will glow on the playa!

We want to raise $8,000 on Indiegogo. Where are those funds going?

Here's an explanation of our budget:

  • Indiegogo fees and reward fulfillment/shipping: $1,600
  • Build site and insurance: $1,500
  • Materials cost (steel, fiberglass, consumables and some equipment): $6,500
  • Lighting (LEDs): $1,000
  • Generator for lighting and fuel: $1,200
  • Labor for fabrication: $8,000
  • Labor for design work: $1,500
  • Engineering analysis: $2,800
  • Transportation (to and from Burning Man): $2,500
  • On-site insurance (at Burning Man): $1,100
  • Storage of the piece (post Burning Man and until we can get it to another site or back at Burning Man next year!): $1,000
  • Campaign video: $1,000

Total project cost: $29,700 (including Indiegogo fees/rewards)

Indiegogo target: $8,000

Other funds raised: $22,000 (from Burning Man and personal donors)

You can also take a look at our timeline below:

  • September 2015: Pooja and Virtox begin designing what will become Fractal Rock
  • January 2016: Design is somewhat finalized. Application process for Burning Man grant begins
  • March 2016: Burning Man Honorarium Art grant is awarded. Build planning begins in earnest.
  • April 2016: Indiegogo campaign video is recorded and produced.
  • June 2016: Indiegogo campaign launches and runs throughout June. Structural engineering analysis and shop drawings produced. Building of internal steel structure commences.
  • July 2016: Building of external steel structure takes place
  • August 2016: Finishing of the piece with fiberglass and preparation for transportation to the playa
  • August 22, 2016: Build crew arrives onsite to install Fractal Rock at Black Rock City!
  • September 2016: Burning Man runs through the first week of September! Then we pack up and bring Fractal Rock back home, storing it somewhere until we can find another place to install it or bring it back to the playa next year.
  • October 2016: Finish fulfilling and shipping rewards that haven't already been fulfilled!

I'll deal with the simpler issue first: transportation. Our plan is to build Fractal Rock in four sections, with one vertical axis and one horizontal (but not in the most obvious way). All pieces will be fully constructed at our workshop, and once completed, we will load them onto a 24' flatbed truck, bring them on playa, and use on-playa cranes to assemble the pieces. 

If you've been following this project, you'll notice that we've changed from our former plans to use foam to construct the piece and will now be building the structure purely out of steel and fiberglass! We're constructing the piece in the following four parts:

  1. INTERNAL SUPPORT: An internal steel support structure that is being engineered by the external structural engineering firm Rbhu and will be fabricated by steel fabricators
  2. EXTERNAL STEEL CAGE: An external steel cage this is composed of thousands of small steel triangles that are welded together (think the Bliss Project sculptures)
  3. WIRE MESH: A layer of wire mesh to cover this steel cage
  4. FIBERGLASS EXTERIOR: A fiberglass exterior for finishing that will polish the piece and add structural strength

We started our structural analysis of the piece early on to ensure that it would be safe, and as mentioned above, we have been working with an external engineering firm that has experience with Burning Man projects. Their expertise and our research will yield a beautiful, strong piece.


We're doing our build in the Bay Area, and could use assistance on any of the following tasks:

  • Steel fabrication (cutting, shaping, welding, assembly)
  • Fiberglass coating
  • Finding another home for Fractal Rock after Burning Man

If you're interested, please fill out this form!

Thank you for reading about our project. We hope you get a chance to experience Fractal Rock in some way, whether it is through our 3D printed rewards, VR experience, in-person at Burning Man, or even just through this campaign page! If we see you at the burn, please be sure to say hi! If you want to reach out, you can email us at fractalrock2016@gmail.com.

Attribution: 

Thank you to Bryan Perez, our talented videographer!

Some of the Burning Man footage we used in the video was published under a Creative Commons license. The footage can be found here.

Timeline: This is a large project, and Burning Man is in 3 months. This is why we've spent the last several months planning, finding a crew, and figuring out exactly how we're going to build this thing. We've worked out a build schedule that will ensure we get the piece done in time. We're also working with experienced fabricators who know the ins and outs of building for Burning Man, so we're confident we can do this well.

Budget: One risk is that there could be unforeseen costs that might go way over budget and risk the project. In order to prevent this danger from occurring, we have researched all costs carefully. In many cases, we've been discussing costs for months with vendors and laborers. We're pretty confident in our budgeting for this project. There is, of course, the risk that we will not meet the fundraising goal. If we do not meet the Indiegogo goal, we will still complete this project (this is possible because of the grant we have received) but might have to complete it at slightly smaller scale. 

Structural engineering: We've been consulting with an external structural engineering firm, who are working with us to design the structure and give it an engineer's stamp of approval.

Crew: We've got a solid core team, consisting of the two artists, a project manager, a lighting and build manager, and a fiberglass expert. This is the minimum that we would need in order to make this project a reality, but if you are interested in volunteering, we'd love your help! Please email us at fractalrock2016@gmail.com and/or fill out this form!

Rewards: The hand-crafted rewards (the 3D printed models and bases) have been planned for and are already being worked on. I have also identified and vetted suppliers for the rewards that are not hand-crafted and have done careful research into shipping and material costs for all rewards. These estimates have been included in our budget calculations.

story:
Hello I'm Fat Apollo and I have a dream.

A dream of an experience that will excite all 6 senses and revolutionize how people relate to each other.

I want to establish the first ever One-on-One Ball Pit experience.

This ball pit will be portable, will measure 96 x 48 x 48 and hold an awesome 4.75 cubic yards.

This will be large enough for two adults to comfortably sit and face each other neck deep in balls.

I intend to use this pit, not just for communing with friends, but also for a new series called “Tales from the Ball-Pit” where celebrities will join me and reveal their deepest secrets.

The money we raise will be used to purchase:

  1. The pit

  2. The balls

  3. A ladder


I am looking to you to help make it come true.

The perks that are available are listed to the side, if you are outside Halifax please add shipping costs, if noted.


There will be stretch goals as well, stay tuned!

story:
Who I Am

My name is Paul Dietrick. I am a live projection artist, musician, and video designer who creates interactive, audio-reactive, video-mapped installations for events under the alias Stingray Bob, based out of Philadelphia. I strive to link the audiovisual experience for the audience, resulting in a synaesthetic environment for the participants. I also have a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering and am currently working on product design for several clients. 

While out of town July 20th weekend, my car was broken into and ransacked, I lost video, lighting, and music equipment, tools, the vehicle registration, and my rear passenger door window, My insurance was unable to cover any of the losses and it appears the police will not be able to help recover the items. I filed a police report but have not heard back from them yet.

I have been self employed for 10 months and I have not needed any financial assistance in that time due to my bookings and work schedule. While I have been able to earn a livable salary as a freelancer I do not have the funds saved that would allow me to replace the items that were stolen which would allow me to continue to earn a living.

I humbly ask for donations to help me replace my gear. I have never been in this position of needing donations and I find this very challenging. As a show of my appreciation, I will be creating a custom projection mapped installation exclusively for the contributors and will be giving away original music and a special DJ mixes.


What I Need & What You Get

The value of the stolen items is conservatively about $2240. Since not all of the items are directly related to my business, I do not expect to hit this goal so any money I receive will be spent on the first list below. 

The items which I absolutely need replaced are the following:

Hitachi Drill and Light Set + Screws - $90

Craftsman 56pc Universal Mechanics Tool Set - $80

Arrow T50 Heavy Duty Staple Gun + 1/2" Staples - $30

30ft Tape Measure - $25

Large bag of various length zip ties - $15

Bag of various size spring clamps - $15

3- Startech VGA Video Extender Over CAT5 - $300

2- 1.5" Galvanized Pipe Flange - $30 

1.5" Galvanized Pipe Tee Fitting - $20

Rear Passenger Door Window - $25

Vehicle Registration - $90


The items which are less important to replace are the following:

Behringer ULTRABASS BX300 Bass Combo Amp (discontinued) - $190

Chauvet COLORado 6 LED (discontinued) - $1300

2- 46" Circular Projection Screen (replace wood frame which was broken) - $30


After the donation period ends, I will be creating a custom projection mapped installation for your eyes only. It will be in Philadelphia, sometime in October. If you cannot make it to the event, there will be a video taken that will be distributed online. I will create animations which feature the names and faces of the good folks who donate to my cause. These animations will be projected onto the installation. The more money you contribute, the more your name will be highlighted and customized. I will also be creating a custom DJ mix for this installation and will give contributors a CD or a digital download of this mix. 


The Impact

Without my tools and equipment, I simply cannot keep making the art which sustains myself and inspires so many others. As a small business owner, I do not have the means to replace a loss of this magnitude, Your donations will help me to keep producing art. 


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you cannot contribute money there are many ways in which you can help:

    -A hug or a word of encouragement

    -Gifting an item comparable to the ones on my list

    -Sharing this page with friends who may want to help

    -Help planning the "Thank You" Installation in October

    -Search craigslist, Ebay, pawn shops, and flea markets near NE Philadelphia for my items

    -Be careful and do not leave your possessions in your vehicle

story:
Short Summary

Seven Traces is a nomadic Contemporary Arts Festival with a focus on public and site-specific art. Every year, for a few weeks we occupy a new city/town anywhere in the world with art by seven artists. Inevitably, some art will leave traces after it's been taken down for years after the festival is over. 

We have piloted the festival last year in Lancaster, England as part of a Masters course, and this year the festival is happening in Caernarfon, Wales.

With this campaign we hope to raise funds for this year's festival: to bring 7 artists from the Wales, England, and Norway together in Caernarfon for a compelling festival of multiple artform ranging from visual to performing arts.

The aim over the years is to create a network of traces and memories the growing collection of which will be an exhibition in itself.


What We Need & What You Get

At this point we only need £1,088.5 and we are looking to raise as much as we can from private sources (all of you wonderful people, universities, etc.), rather than relying on the public purse.

We need: 

£700 for the artistic fees at £100 per artist. 
£303.5 for travel expenses for all the artists.
£85 for accomodation.

Whoever funds the whole festival and donates at least a 50% of the entire sum to Seven Traces in return will make his/her town or city next year's destination, and in addition to that will be able to commission any of the existing artists to create a public work of art in his town or city. 

The perk for the person who funds the entire sum will be Seven Traces coming to his/her city or town next year, wherever in the world it is. 

Other perks include free merchandise from the artists, discounts on artwork, and much more!

If we don't reach our goal the festival will still happen! We are fundraising from a range of sources and are not dependent solely on this campaign, although we hope it will be a substantial addition.

    The Impact

    Through international travel and public art we hope to make art more accessible to real people. We don't want to hide everything in galleries or concert halls, we want to bring art to the streets, the abandoned buildings, and all the places you would never think art could happen.

    Having successfuly piloted the festival last year we feel confident that the festival will have a growing impact on every place we show, as said previously, we want to leave behind traces of what we did, whether these are physical traces of artwork or someone's memories.

    Risks & Challenges

    Seven Traces includes people from last year and a number of new artists. Along being artists we are all experienced in organising aristic projects. The artists are of different ages and work in different artforms, this gives us a wide range of available experience and expertise; we also have access to our mentors (senior artists and arts professionals) that can advise us in complicated situations.

    Our main challenges are bringing together artists from different countries and managing an entire festival digitally. While being complicated, this is an integral part of the festival from its outset, and feeds into the nomadic and decentralised concept of the festival.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Each retweet and share is huge help, if you can't help financially, please help us by spreading the word. We want to make Seven Traces a truly international event connecting continents, and we can't do it without your help!
story_txt:
Short Summary Seven Traces is a nomadic Contemporary Arts Festival with a focus on public and site-specific art. Every year, for a few weeks we occupy a new city/town anywhere in the world with art by seven artists. Inevitably, some art will leave traces after it's been taken down for years after the festival is over. 
We have piloted the festival last year in Lancaster, England as part of a Masters course, and this year the festival is happening in Caernarfon, Wales.
With this campaign we hope to raise funds for this year's festival: to bring 7 artists from the Wales, England, and Norway together in Caernarfon for a compelling festival of multiple artform ranging from visual to performing arts.
The aim over the years is to create a network of traces and memories the growing collection of which will be an exhibition in itself.

What We Need & What You Get
 At this point we only need £1,088.5 and we are looking to raise as much as we can from private sources (all of you wonderful people, universities, etc.), rather than relying on the public purse.
We need: 
£700 for the artistic fees at £100 per artist. £303.5 for travel expenses for all the artists.£85 for accomodation.
Whoever funds the whole festival and donates at least a 50% of the entire sum to Seven Traces in return will make his/her town or city next year's destination, and in addition to that will be able to commission any of the existing artists to create a public work of art in his town or city. 
The perk for the person who funds the entire sum will be Seven Traces coming to his/her city or town next year, wherever in the world it is. 
Other perks include free merchandise from the artists, discounts on artwork, and much more!
If we don't reach our goal the festival will still happen! We are fundraising from a range of sources and are not dependent solely on this campaign, although we hope it will be a substantial addition.

  The Impact Through international travel and public art we hope to make art more accessible to real people. We don't want to hide everything in galleries or concert halls, we want to bring art to the streets, the abandoned buildings, and all the places you would never think art could happen.
Having successfuly piloted the festival last year we feel confident that the festival will have a growing impact on every place we show, as said previously, we want to leave behind traces of what we did, whether these are physical traces of artwork or someone's memories.
Risks & Challenges
 Seven Traces includes people from last year and a number of new artists. Along being artists we are all experienced in organising aristic projects. The artists are of different ages and work in different artforms, this gives us a wide range of available experience and expertise; we also have access to our mentors (senior artists and arts professionals) that can advise us in complicated situations.
Our main challenges are bringing together artists from different countries and managing an entire festival digitally. While being complicated, this is an integral part of the festival from its outset, and feeds into the nomadic and decentralised concept of the festival.

  Other Ways You Can Help Each retweet and share is huge help, if you can't help financially, please help us by spreading the word. We want to make Seven Traces a truly international event connecting continents, and we can't do it without your help!

story:
Artefact is an independent coffee shop, work space and art gallery in Stirchley Birmingham.

We started out as P Cafe in 2015. We've learnt a lot since then, and as we've built and grown inside the space - one thing stayed the same. We still couldn't collectively decide on one thing that the P in P Cafe stood for. We also found ourselves a wonderful mix of poetry, art, home-made cakes and coffee.

As this mix of art-forms stood in the face of 2017, we decided that we needed a new name, some new handmade furniture and a new exhibition to show it all off in. So here we are, Artefact.

Artefact ˈɑːtɪfakt/ noun Definition:

1. an object made by a human being, typically one of cultural or historical interest. "gold and silver artefacts"

2. something observed in a scientific investigation or experiment that is not naturally present but occurs as a result of the preparative or investigative procedure.
 

Our open call for responses to our new name, in the site specific context of Stirchley (which is where we have been lovingly based, ever since we first opened) has given us some amazing artworks. We'd actually love to properly print/frame and prepare the cafe to exhibit these works.

We are looking to raise £500 to help us do this.

The money will go towards printing costs, exhibition material, gifts to thank our participating artists for all their hard work as well as creating spaces and opportunity for future artists and art events.

Exhibition artists are:

Fred Hubble, Jonathan Wright, Suzi Osborn, Lucy Hutchinson, Sophie Huckfield, Duncan Poulton, Liz Hardy, Antonio Roberts and James Kennedy.

We'd be really grateful for your support and in return will be offering the following perks in exchange (guaranteed to strike your fancy!)

  • £5: many thanks, for you there'll be a free coffee and cake!
  • £10: many many thanks, a free coffee and sandwich for 1 
  • £20: many splendid thank yous, an afternoon tea for 2 (two coffees, two sandwiches and two cakes!)
  • £40: thank you, thank you, thank you! An A3 limited edition print from a selection in the exhibition
  • £50: we'd throw a parade for you if we could! How about a limited edition cushion from exhibition?

We make a real effort to source our bread and cakes from home-made and local sources. Our bread is from the local Stirchley bakery Loaf, our jams and chutneys are from  Cuffufle Preserves, and our cakes are from home bakers, (including Mrs Mills Makes Cakes from Kings Norton, and vegan/gluten free goodies from Deb's Pantry)

The Impact

  • We've hosted a number of exhibitions that involve community engagement, and want to continue to do so. Stirchley Speaks, which is a monthly spoken word event at the cafe - has been running ever since June 2015, as well as our free creative writing meet ups. We've also exhibited the work of many local Stirchley artists.
  • We want to set the bar higher for ourselves, to keep encouraging others to use our space for their own projects. We can do this by actively using the space ourselves, and hopefully inspiring others to do the same.
  • You'll be able to come and see the exhibition at the private view (when it's all done) and admire your handywork by actually seeing where your donations have gone to.

Risks & Challenges

What if we don't raise the money?

  • The exhibition will go on anyway! We love the work and we can't imagine not exhibiting it.
  • We'd still love for you to come and see it, ask us about our space, or even just get in touch about your own projects.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, help us out by sharing the information about our upcoming artists! 

  • You can share a link to their page or even ours.
  • You can attend one of our other events in the future

And that's all there is to it :)

story:
Göra MakerSpace

You might be asking yourself, why would I care about a makerspace in Medellín, Colombia? 

To us, a makerspace and the maker movement, are about much more than just a room full of tools and machinery.  It represents an alternative.  We see the maker movement as the new Declaration of Independence.  However, this declaration does not seek liberation from any imperial nation, it seeks only to break the chains that currently limit our creativity.  For we have always been free, and always will be, no matter where we live. The maker movement is about acknowledging that very freedom in a time where it has never been more accessible.  Makerspaces are the platforms from which this freedom can be realized, If the internet democratized access to information, makerspaces will democratize the capacity to produce. From a makerspace we can truly leverage our combined human knowledge and experiences and transform them into useful solutions and innovations.  

The maker movement represents a new paradigm.  It's a new way of thinking, a profound global cultural rebirth. It provides the foundation to experience life in a new and more fulfilling way. To make is to share, every time you make something you leave a piece of yourself in that which you created. There is no greater gift to give than this, nor any greater gift to receive.

Medellín is a vibrant city full of creativity and passion.  Help us unlock this city's massive potential and show the world what people can accomplish when they come together for a common goal!

Our Community's Growth:

Thomas King alone in his apartement in Medellín trying to build a 3D printer (May 2014):

20 Mission, our first space. 

Before: (April 2015):

After:

AtomHouse, our second space.  

Before: (August 2015):

After:

Latina Stereo, our current space.Before (February 2016) :



Now:
Original Campaign Video:


Impact

Despite our challenges over the first year (most pressing being our lack of serious tools and our own space to create) we have spread the maker movement throughout the city and have seen the birth and growth of maker businesses:

  • Ventus - a drone software company with a marketplace for drone apps (www.appsdrones.com) 
  • Maker Colombia - Educational robotics kits  (http://makercolombia.com/)
  • EMET Robotics - Build and teach advanced robotics (http://www.emet-robotics.com/)
  • Me&Co - Mechanical engineering company 
  • El Guardian - An app to provide sober drivers in the city (https://www.facebook.com/El-Guardian-Conductore...)

Risks and Challenges

At Göra we've been working hard for over a year to bring Medellín its first makerspace.  We've identified our two biggest challenges in bringing Medellín the makerspace it needs.

1. Our lack of a fixed location to build the community 

2. Our lack of a serious selection of tools and machinery.

Acquiring the space and tools we need are only the beginning of our journey.  We will face other challenges to be sure:

Building a thriving community is our main goal, and in order to do that we must be a sustainable operation.  It will be difficult to find the right equilibrium between remaining accessible to as many people as possible and maintaining a manageable community size that allows sustainability.  For example, if we charge a very cheap rate then we will need a lot of members to be sustainable which we currently cannot handle and if we charge a very high rate we will be denying access to many of the people we wish to collaborate with.  

What we are doing to overcome this challenge:

  • Communicate with other makerspaces from all over the world to gain insight from their experiences and re-evaluate our own.
  • Reach out to other local small business to gain support and guidance.
  • Collaborate with other local businesses in ways to help with promotion and seek sustainability together.
  • Maintain the lowest costs possible.
  • Gather feedback from our members and the community.
  • Acquire the necessary business consultations we need to properly address our challenges.

Other challenges include navigating the Colombian legal environment in terms of insurance and employment laws.  We have found quality lawyers to help us, but they're not free! 


Perks!

We have a unique list of perks from the local makers and artists in Medellín:



• When I moved to Medellín I didn't exactly realize I was moving from one valley to another - this is a poster meant to recognize the mountain connection between two valleys from differets worlds.

• One of two original paintings by Medellín artist Turbo!

• Maker stickers - pixelated maker tools!

• A personalized maker profile picture - we make a illustrated maker figure of your face!

• Choose one of two Limited edition Posters by Medellín artist Turbo (1m X 70cm)

• Alpha version of local maker company, Maker Colombia's, intro to robotics kit with Dipper the Robot.

• From the sewers of Medellín, Göra T-shirts!

• Denver manhole cover sweaters.

• Looking to develop a new idea in a creative and unique environment - 6 month membership to Göra makerspace.

• Looking to develop a new idea in a creative and unique environment - 1 year membership to Göra makerspace.

• Looking to develop a new idea in a creative and unique environment - 2 year membership to Göra makerspace

• Local Maker made drone.

• Graffiti/art tour in Medellín - meet the artists!

• Choose from one of two open source designs to 3D print



Traditional Wooden Toy 

Poster Pack

  


  


·  Illustration workshop

·  Customized Thank You Illustration.

We Need to Raise at least $20,000! 

Here is a list of some of the first things that we want to have in our makerspace. With $20,000 the first two things we will spend money on are a laser cutter and securing our own place with at least six months rent in the bank.  This is a wish list for the amount of space we want to have and the machines and tools we would fill it up with (with growth in mind!): 

With a warehouse of 8,503 sq. ft. we could have an amazing place to start. That would  work well for the first two years.  We could however start with less and just sign only a one year lease, but we expect rapid growth after the first year.  We have approximates for how much space each work section will require:

Carpentry – 120 m2 (384 sq. ft.)

Welding – 100 m2 (320 sq. ft.)

Electronics – 30 m2 (96 sq. ft.)

3D Printing – 50 m2 (160 sq. ft.)

Sewing – 50 m2 (160 sq. ft.)

Painting – 30 m2 (96 sq. ft.)

Design – 40 m2 (128 sq. ft.)

CNC – 70 m2 (224 sq. ft.)

Water Cutter – 100 m2 (320 sq. ft.)

Garden – 80 m2 (256 sq. ft.)

Community – 40 m2 (128 sq. ft.)

Kitchen – 50 m2 (160 sq. ft.)

Lobby – 20 m2 (64 sq. ft.)

Lockers – 10 m2 (30 sq. ft.)

(gallery – 60 m2/192 sq. ft.)

Total= 574 m2/6178 sq ft.

Expensive Machinery Needed:

Wood working basics:

CNC Machine – X carve = $1,279

Wood Lathe – Central Machinery = $299

Drill Press - $200

Jig Saw manual – Milwaukee 720w 500- 3000 rpm -  $200

Circular Saw – ¼’’ 1800w 5800 rpm - $250

Router – Milwaukee 1 ¾ 1320w 24000 rpm - $300

Industrial Vacuum – Rigid - $200

Total = $2,728.00

Mechanical Tool Basics

Electric Polisher - $200

Welding Helmet x 2 - $300

Compound Miter Saw - $220

Total: $ 720

Miscellaneous Tool List

Laser Cutter – $15,000

Lulzbot TAZ 5 3D Printer - $2,200

B9Creator DLP 3D Printer - $3,500

Serger Machine - $650

Rent 6 months 

Total: $21,350

Grand Total: $24,798

Other Ways You Can Help

Share! Share! Share! 

Please help us spread the word.  Share our story with all your friends and family if you connect to it in anyway.  

Also we are always grateful to receive tool and supply donations.  Send us an email at goraspace@gmail.com if you'd like to send us tools or supplies!  Unlike in the United States, it is less likely to receive tool and supply donations that otherwise would have been thrown away because people here do not simply throw things away when they are old.

story:
What are Meowchi?

Meowchi are sweet mochi kittens that come in a range of flavors and variants. Created in 2012 by our artist, Ryan Zanfei, they have quickly become a staple character of our brand! The first standard 5 inch sized Meowchi plush was produced within that first year. Since then, we've created over 20 flavors and variants of these palm sized kittens!

What is Tasty Peach Studios?

We are a sweet, unique boutique that sells adorable, indie merchandise inspired by Japan! Every character and design is made by our artist with love and care. We started off in 2007 in our Etsy shop crafting hand made clay charms and jewelry. Since then we have grown to become one of the leading Indie brands on the convention circuit, providing high quality metal jewelry, accessories, plush, apparel, and so much more!

So why Indiegogo?

One of the biggest requests we have had for this character is bigger versions. Our Kickstarter successfully funded these guys' first run with an overwhelming 150K campaign! But as we stated before, bigger plush means higher production costs and the need for extra storage space.

The Kickstarter allowed us to purchase a large warehouse to store a lot of our merchandise and goodies in, but we're still only able to take up so much space with the Giant Meowchi we're funding on Indiegogo! That means they'll be available once a year, early each year for pre-orders! So this year we've chosen Indiegogo to host these orders to hopefully fund another round of these cuties! With Indiegogo we also don't need to reach a "goal" to be successful, we just collect the funds and orders what you pay for! So there will be LITTLE TO NO EXTRAS!

When getting any plush made, there are always many steps from start to finish, including multiple revisions to the initial design. Like all plush, each Meowchi started off as a concept design. Luckily for you, this round requires none of that! However here is a close up of each plush design in concept and final design form!











Since all 6 of these prototypes are perfected and ready to go, there will be a very short window between the campaigns funding and the final product being sent out! June / July 2018 is when we are estimating fulfillment to begin. If all plush are finished early however, we will begin fulfillment immediately! We will make additional updates if products arrive early!

Since all items are already set to go, there will not be any additional stretch goals, freebies, or additional rewards this time. Those are staying exclusive to the original event, and so we plan to create a very simple set up for this Indiegogo campaign! Six tiers, 1-2-3-4-5 or 6 plush, and that's that. Simple, quick, and to the point for those ready to purchase their first, or maybe an additional Giant Meowchi.


As Giant Meowchi are much more expensive to produce than smaller plush, the starting goal of this project is to raise $5,000 to order minimum quantities of all 6 plush. This goal amount will also cover shipping costs and any fees associated with Indiegogo and payment services.


The Giant Meowchi Ingiegogo Campaign will run for 30 days and will conclude early March. Since there is no additional goal to hit we will be purchasing ONLY what is ordered by you, the backers.

This means that if you do not pledge to this campaign to get one, you will probably be unable to acquire one until next year's campaign in January 2019 (to be fulfilled mid 2019. Plush will be ready to ship approximately 3-4 months after the end of the Indiegogo (June or July).

The process takes approximately 2-3 months for production to complete and 1-1.5 months to ship all items to our warehouse. The approximate in hand dates are estimated for June / July 2018. As soon as the plush are in hand we will make multiple announcements here and on all social media and shipments will begin!

Risks and challenges

Tasty Peach Studios has been manufacturing, producing, shipping, and organizing large plush projects for the past 7 years now!

From manufacturer delays and lost shipments, to damaged shipping containers and stolen merchandise, we've experienced most every problem and obstacle one could actually encounter in the plush manufacturing process. Over the years, we've solved these problems and moved forward successfully to be the top indie plush brand on the convention circuit today.

Giant Meowchi are the only large pre-order project that is currently ongoing, meaning it has our full attention. Additionally, there is no outside company involved with the review and approval of this project. All we need is approval from you, our fans.

We strive to be extremely transparent with our fan base and pride ourselves on proper, consistent, & open communication with them if any problems arise. If there are any issues with this project, they will be messaged promptly to all backers so that they are aware of them in detail with the steps we are taking to correct them.

Thank you for reading our Indiegogo and we hope to be sending you a Giant Meowchi soon!
story_txt:
What are Meowchi?
Meowchi are sweet mochi kittens that come in a range of flavors and variants. Created in 2012 by our artist, Ryan Zanfei, they have quickly become a staple character of our brand! The first standard 5 inch sized Meowchi plush was produced within that first year. Since then, we've created over 20 flavors and variants of these palm sized kittens!
What is Tasty Peach Studios?
We are a sweet, unique boutique that sells adorable, indie merchandise inspired by Japan! Every character and design is made by our artist with love and care. We started off in 2007 in our Etsy shop crafting hand made clay charms and jewelry. Since then we have grown to become one of the leading Indie brands on the convention circuit, providing high quality metal jewelry, accessories, plush, apparel, and so much more!
So why Indiegogo?
One of the biggest requests we have had for this character is bigger versions. Our Kickstarter successfully funded these guys' first run with an overwhelming 150K campaign! But as we stated before, bigger plush means higher production costs and the need for extra storage space.The Kickstarter allowed us to purchase a large warehouse to store a lot of our merchandise and goodies in, but we're still only able to take up so much space with the Giant Meowchi we're funding on Indiegogo! That means they'll be available once a year, early each year for pre-orders! So this year we've chosen Indiegogo to host these orders to hopefully fund another round of these cuties! With Indiegogo we also don't need to reach a "goal" to be successful, we just collect the funds and orders what you pay for! So there will be LITTLE TO NO EXTRAS!

When getting any plush made, there are always many steps from start to finish, including multiple revisions to the initial design. Like all plush, each Meowchi started off as a concept design. Luckily for you, this round requires none of that! However here is a close up of each plush design in concept and final design form!Since all 6 of these prototypes are perfected and ready to go, there will be a very short window between the campaigns funding and the final product being sent out! June / July 2018 is when we are estimating fulfillment to begin. If all plush are finished early however, we will begin fulfillment immediately! We will make additional updates if products arrive early!Since all items are already set to go, there will not be any additional stretch goals, freebies, or additional rewards this time. Those are staying exclusive to the original event, and so we plan to create a very simple set up for this Indiegogo campaign! Six tiers, 1-2-3-4-5 or 6 plush, and that's that. Simple, quick, and to the point for those ready to purchase their first, or maybe an additional Giant Meowchi.As Giant Meowchi are much more expensive to produce than smaller plush, the starting goal of this project is to raise $5,000 to order minimum quantities of all 6 plush. Plush will be ready to ship approximately 3-4 months after the end of the Indiegogo (June or July).The process takes approximately 2-3 months for production to complete and 1-1.5 months to ship all items to our warehouse. From manufacturer delays and lost shipments, to damaged shipping containers and stolen merchandise, we've experienced most every problem and obstacle one could actually encounter in the plush manufacturing process. Over the years, we've solved these problems and moved forward successfully to be the top indie plush brand on the convention circuit today.
Giant Meowchi are the only large pre-order project that is currently ongoing, meaning it has our full attention. Additionally, there is no outside company involved with the review and approval of this project. All we need is approval from you, our fans.
We strive to be extremely transparent with our fan base and pride ourselves on proper, consistent, & open communication with them if any problems arise. If there are any issues with this project, they will be messaged promptly to all backers so that they are aware of them in detail with the steps we are taking to correct them.

story:
Becoming a Peace Artist

My name is Sarah Queblatin and I have chosen to become a Peace Artist after working in interfaith dialogue and peacebuilding for the last 3 years and 10 years of creative and artistic applications through workshops with children, leaders, and communities. Aside from peace, I also facilitate creative workshops that promote cultural heritage, environmental education; and transformative and healing arts.


Currently, I am designing a peace art program for a children's museum and integrating an art campaign that will work with children to make the call for the end of armed conflict in this generation for the peace talks taking place between the government and armed rebel groups in my country.


On May 31 this year, I received a formal approval for my tuition scholarship for my first year at the European Graduate School for a Masters Degree in Expressive Arts for Conflict Transformation and Peacebuilding. This degree requires a month long visit to Saas – Fee in Switzerland every July. for three years. Everything else will be on distance learning where one can focus on applying the study in one’s chosen community.


My intention is to study sacred and indigenous art themes to develop my practice of transformative and community based art. The plan is to integrate Asian themes with existing  creative and transformative processes and frameworks. The study will be applied with my work with interfaith/intercultural community partners in the Philippines and around Asia to be used in arts relief, dialogue, and community building. My intention is also to work with local culture and wisdom bearers and co-create modules and artworks with them and their community.


Making Peace Work through Creativity

My contribution in the field of conflict transformation and peacebuilding will be through developing creative mechanisms that further validate the importance of interior factors and processes like interfaith dialogue, creativity, and indigenous wisdom as vital components to achieving integral sustainable development.


The study and the practice will also be documenting traditional arts, wisdom and practice that can contribute to the wealth of existing peacebuilding approaches.


The output of the study will be co-created modules and artworks together with local culture bearers and their community members that will be used for arts relief, dialogue, and community building.


This year, my intention is to benefit and work with interfaith/intercultural communities in Metro Manila and Mindanao to bridge the people to creative and peaceful solutions to armed conflict in the country. The next two years will be work around conflict affected areas in Asia. 

 

Let's Have a Co-Creative Partnership


Because I have consciously decided to be an artist surviving as a consultant for project management jobs since late last year instead of doing full time work that has regular pay, my funds are not enough to support myself for this trip. I come from a middle class family with simple needs and I do not wish to burden my parents for they have already given me so much to help me become the empowered adult that I am now.


This peace starts with myself. So I am now embodying this intention for peace by connecting with you. Believe me it has been a challenge to ask.I am trying to consciously use the word "invitation" instead of "challenge" now. I only have barely a month to fundraise since I got my tuition scholarship formally approved. I even went through doubts asking myself why I should go through all this trouble and stress. So after playing cha-cha with the universe, I asked myself WHY NOT? So all this is an invitation  to humility, sharing, and abundance!


I am raising $5,500 for the following:

1.  Round Trip Air Ticket to Zurich, Switzerland - $1,500

2.  Lodging at Hotel Allalin (required venue for stay) - $ 2,700

3.  Travel Allowance for train transfers and pocket money  - $ 800

4. I didn't mention this in the video but If there's extra, I'd like to buy a new netbook or upgrade my 4 year old Asus Laptop that needs keyboard and memory repair - $ 500


Please see the wonderful perks I can share as energy exchange for your support. If you have other ideas. Let's talk.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please send this to 5 people whom you feel can share blessings and please include a personal testimonial :-) 


For more information:

Click to View my Arts Portfolio

Click to View my CV:

Click to View my Scholarship Acceptance

Click to Know more about my course at the European Graduate School

story:
For over 10 years we have been gathering free of charge in order to celebrate the wonderful weirdness that is this life. This year circumstances have altered the previous arrangements and for the first time we are asking for financial help in making Duganfest happen.

We need $500 to secure the location.  I will, as always, foot the bill on the food and the first round or two but i cannot swing the normal costs in addition to this years location fee.

Should we not reach our goal there will still be a 'Fest of sorts just nothing like we've known Duganfest to be.  We will most likely do lunch at Chili's or something.


Whatever the outcome of this endeavor I appreciate your help and friendship.

story:
THE PROJECT:

You are photogenic. Let me show you!

I am doing a FREE photo session for you. I would like to photograph you, with an object chosen by you. The most recent art works created by you, things that you've been using since 11 years old, hats you are preparing for your expecting baby, the gift that your ex gave you, indulge your imagination! Bring whatever you want to be in your portrait.  You are going to get a unique edited portrait.

 

Reserve your shoot by clicking here: http://www.doodle.com/8rfpbchexkbgtttg Photo shoots are available from today to 19th July, 2012. Please reserve at least 3 days in advance and let me know once you reserved. zhengnadia@gmail.com

**************PLEASE DO CONTACT ME AFTER RESERVING!**************

Reservation without contacting me will be deleted 24 hours after they are taken, because I really want to take pictures of who want their photos.Please leave your name when you are reserving. The names are only open to me.

 

http://nadiazheng.com

http://www.facebook.com/NadiaZhengPhotography

 

WHAT I’ll GIVE:

-        A professional photo shoot in studio

-        A digital version of an edited photo of you

 

WHAT I NEED FROM YOU:

support and money.

Share the word. Talk to your friends! Everyone deserves a good portrait!

 

WHERE IS THE PHOTOSHOOT?

it's going to be in Montreal, Canada.

 

HOW IS THE MONEY GOING TO BE USED?

To pay for the rent of the studio.

 

Thank you all for your support!

story:
The Artist

Dave Gertler is a San Francisco based engineer and artist. An avid burner and lover of all things Black Rock City, he has participated in the creation of art cars and installantions over the last eight years. This year, his team has been awarded a grant from the Burning Man Arts Council to build Hands.

About Hands 

Hands is a structural re-creation of human anatomy. It is a symbol of our human nature to discover, create, and uphold.  Our hands are a primary means of self expression and are of particular interest to our group since many of our livelihoods depend on creation.  Our hands are also a symbol of our personal journeys, survival and creation throughout history.  It is our goal to create an uplifting sensation for participants through the structural pose of these magnified hands and evoke interaction with them and one another.
 
The position of two hands facing each other in a lotus-like pose mirrors the symmetry of our bodies.  This installation could have been one hand, but so often one hand held upright generally signifies rebellion, defiance, or some other harsh action.  At the very least, seeing one hand so pronounced may beg the question, where is the other hand? Two hands represents some of the basic principles of Black Rock City, suggesting togetherness, teamwork, unity and the act of giving and receiving.
 
The concept of organic human anatomy becomes evident through a structure of artificial geometry, made of a square grid of wood panels to form human hands.  Sensation is evident in pulses of light which are intrinsic and alien at the same time.  The cupping of the hands facing one another further encourages the feeling of togetherness and places an emphasis on the act of holding or offering. The artificial elements of construction come to show that our desires and possessions are beyond our nature and yet embody who we are.
 
In order for the full vision of our project to come to fruition, we need to fundraise an additional $2,000. We are asking for support through various channels, including throwing a benefit party for Hands in San Francisco. We hope to achieve at the very least, an amount of $500 through our online campaign. Your funds will help us buy quality materials for building purposes, secure a good work space, and also help us transport Hands to Black Rock city safely and efficiently.
 
To thank you for your support (minimum $25), we will gift you with a pentagon shaped wooden medallion with an image of hands in its upright position, holding this years Man, designed by Dave Gertler. Backers that offer $100 or more will receive a high quality metal medallion of the same image.

Dimensions

  • 12' high off the ground
  • 24' across from the tip of the middle fingers
  • each finger is approx. 1.5' x4'
  • top of each hand is approx. 5' x 7' 

Materials

  • 40 sheets of 4' x 8 x 0.75" thick birch plywood
  • each hand includes a 10' diameter welded steel base weighing approx. 500 lbs.

Illumination

At night, Hands will be illuminated by hundreds of multi-colred LED lights which glow vibrantly from the core of the structure. They are sequenced in patterns which will change based on participant interactions through a sensory triggering system. 

 

Please spread the word about Hands:

Facebook: www.facebook.com/handsburningman
Blog: http://handsburningman.blogspot.com/

story:
Our Story

Amalgamate Dance Company, based in NYC, celebrates 5 Years of Dance! Through-out the past 5 years the dream has become a reality and ADC has made a huge impact within our community and beyond. The goal remains to use dance for a purpose to educate, entertain, and inspire our audiences and students.


We need your help to continue our efforts in 2011 by giving to raise $2,500 by May 16th!

When people work together, things get done!
We are raising funds to increase our impact in the following areas:
  1. Studio & Performance Space Rentals - IMPACT: Provide a big enough space for our growing student and audience bases.
  2. Charitable Projects - IMPACT: Allow our dance to serve a bigger purpose by raising funds for significant causes like cancer and sex trafficking.
  3. Pay Dancers - IMPACT: Support Artists who believe in their purpose and give 100% to their job everyday.
  4. Outreach Events - IMPACT: Allows ADC to build our community and its people through free dance workshops and performances.
  5. Choreography Commissions - IMPACT: Provides us with the materials to produce powerful, original dances that touch people's hearts and lives. 

If we don't meet this goal... we can't impact as many lives!


SUPPORT US BY JOINING US FOR OUR OLD FASHIONED PICNIC SOIREE, SATURDAY, MAY 14!

We're having a party to say Thank You to our donors. If you are interested in learning more about ADC and supporting our efforts this event is for YOU! Join us for fun food, drinks, LIVE MUSIC, dancing, an interactive painting, a silent auction and more!

When: Saturday, May 14, 2011 @ 7pm
Where: West Beth Community Center (West Village) | 55 Bethune St | between Washington & West St | NYC
Why: It's Spring! A chance to celebrate with ADC, meet the Board of Directors and dancers, and learn more about our initiatives!
Attire: Cocktail Festive
Tickets: $25 at www.BrownPaperTickets.com;
Exact Link: http://www.brownpaperticke
Cash only at the door!


What We Need & What You Get

Check out the fun PERKS to the Right!!!

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you have a charity connection?  We are seeking charities to collaborate with, please email Info@AmalgamateDance.com

story:
The Midsummer Wakes 

is our community carnival parade for Newcastle Under Lyme.

We take the names from the local tradition of 'Wakes Weeks' where all the factories of the town would shut down for a fortnight and the potters would flock to the seaside and the fairs would come into town.

This year we are working with Seabridge Primary School, St Mary's Primary School, The Social Agency, and the Aspire Young Tenants group to build images that continue our 2016 Midwinter Wakes theme of FLIGHT.

Midsummer Wakes is brought to you by Newcastle Lanterns, B-Arts, Newcastle U L BID and supported by the Arts Council England. 

How can you help?

 

The Blue Girl is Newcastle Under Lyme's iconic giant puppet. Created by B-Arts for the 2012 Olympic celebrations she is now a feature of local carnival parades, and Newcastle Under Lyme is her home. 

We need YOUR help to bring her back to Newcastle this Summer for the Midsummer Wakes parade. 

Please give what you can and help to bring her out to Midsummer Wakes on Sat 22 July.

story:
Our Story

I have spent the last 10 Years working full time as a Clinical Massage Therapist, while working part time on my jewelry & photography careers. My husband, Thano, has spent many years working in retail management, while spending nights, weekends & days off working as my Lapidary Artist/Mining Stones. We have decided now is the time to make the jump... so as of a month ago we are working FULL TIME to make our jewelry line our main source of income! This is a HUGE leap for us! We can't do it without your help!


We start our process going out into nature to open pit mining areas around the country. Most of the time these are free sites, but every once in a while we will go to a mine that charges a fee. I am also a photographer, so these trips serve a dual purpose (I sell my prints on the same Etsy shop as our jewelry). Often times we have to hike out quite a distance to gather our gemstones, usually in beautiful & secluded nature! The perfect place for a photographer! While mining our stones Thano & I are sending Reiki to the earth & the stones. Once we are home we continue to use Reiki throughout the entire process of creating our jewelry, including the lapidary process, to clear negative energy out of all our materials, while raising the vibration of all of our work. All of our Jewelry is one of a kind.


It is our DREAM to have our Jewelry Line be our main source of income!


What happens if we don't reach our campaign goal?

We will continue to move forward with our plans even if we do not meet our goal, it just may take us a lot longer & we may have to go back to part time work on our dream.

The money will go toward what it can, we may not be able to get everything on our list, but we'll get what we can.


What We Need & What You Get

We need to buy Jewelry & Lapidary equipment and supplies.

Including but not limited to: raw sterling silver, new lapidary saws/blades/ grinding wheels/ sandpaper etc., jewelry tools, flex shaft drill, drill bits, solder, torch, gasses (propane & oxygen).


We need to fund mining trips to gather stones for our jewelry.

We are looking to go back to Pala, Ca for tourmaline.

We would like to go to Oregon for sunstone. We also have many more close trips planned for petrified wood, jasper and more. 


We also need to pay for website hosting services, our website is currently being hosted for free & it has ads across the top, something we would like to change asap! erindonnellyellis.com


We are looking to do a lot of craft events this year, so we need to fund entry & jury fees, a canopy & weights, tables & display (we have one table, 2 chairs & some display, but we will need more).


We are also looking to move our studio!


Please view our Perks for all the things you can redeem!

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help by spreading the word about us & our project! You can also support us by visiting one of the locations currently selling our work!

My work is available at: erindonnellyellis.etsy.com

story:
“The library will change people’s lives in the same way it has changed mine” 

-Javier Carrillo

Artist and printmaking instructor 

WHO ARE WE

We are Art Division, a non-profit organization dedicated to training underserved 18 to 25 year old young adults who show genuine commitment to the visual arts.

We are located in the Rampart District of Los Angeles. Through professional training, individual tutoring and direct contact  with working artists, our students develop the tools they need to pursue higher education, achieve self-sufficiency and begin  careers in the arts and related fields.

We started in 2010 with the help of LA Housing Partnership who donated a space for our library and classes. We provide our students with free art and art history classes, field trips, and a comprehensive Art Library. 

The heart of our program is our Art Library. We carry more than 5,000 books which were donated by members of the Los Angeles art community. 

But we have outgrown our space and we need your help

We are raising money to open a new art library. It is important to have a sophisticated art library in the Rampart District because we truly believe that looking through art books and reading about art can change lives. The books have had an enormous effect on our students and their work.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU RECEIVE  

Our mission is to create an art library that it is easily accessible to our students and community. We will provide free art history lectures to local residents including neighborhood high school and college students.  We recently received a donation of a large space for our library. However there is a need for extensive remodeling.  We will need chairs, tables, and lights. We also need funds for librarians and staff. 

Before our library can open, we need to raise $6,500 

This a flexible funding campaign, which means all the money raised will support the Art Library. 

We hope to implement a program of public Art History lectures and events in the summer of 2013.

We are also creating partnerships with other neighborhood non-profits in order to introduce art books to our community.

As a THANK YOU from Art Division, our students and staff have put together gifts for you.

Perks: 

*All donors will be thanked on our website. *

*Your contribution is 100% tax deductible.*

  • With your donation of $10  you will receive three greeting cards designed by our staff and students. Please include your shipping address.

                             

  • With your donation of $25 you will receive one original block print designed by one of our students. You have the option to pick  from three. Please include your shipping address and the design you would like. 

 

                              Design 1 - T.V Boy

                               

                                                                    Jairo Perez

 

                              Design 2 -  Aztec Warrior 

                              

                                                            Jonathan Romero

                              Design 3 - Design II

                              

                                                                 Victor Reyes

  • With your donation of $50 you will receive an etching designed by student Alex Gonzalez aka "Otis Woods". Created exclusively for this campaign, it is a limited edition of 50.

        

 

  • With your donation of $100 you will receive a limited edition etching by artist Javier Carrillo.

 

                              

 

  • With your donation of $200 you will receicve a commission portrait drawing of your choice by student Jairo Perez. Please include photograph.

 

 

                    

 

  • With your donation of $500 you will receive an etching by Art Division founder and artist Dan McCleary.

 

                              

 

 

  • With your donation of $900 you will receive a lithograph " The Chef" by Art Division founder and artist Dan McCleary.

                             

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  •  You can help us in valuable ways !
  • "Like Us" on our Facebook page
  • Spread the word
  • Share our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Donate Art Books 

Thank you so much for your time and help . If you have any questions about donationg art books or would like a tour of our space, please contact us at maria@artdivision.org.

story:
Short Summary

Hi everyone! This is a very simple fundraiser - I am looking to apple to rent a booth and sell some paintings at the McMichael Art Gallery's Autumn Art Sale. If you're never been, check out the link and definitely take a trip there if you're ever in Toronto: 

http://www.mcmichael.com

I recently won the City of Vaughan's Practicing Artist of the Year award and I am currently studying arts administration in business school. 

Please see my website:

www.artbyamandac.blogspot.ca 

What I Need & What You Get

I require a total of $150 (I had to set the minimum as $500 as per Indiegogo's rules) in order to rent the booth. 

Please check out the list of perks, as well as my website to see some of the art that I do! 

The Impact

I am in the process of establishing myself as a professional artist - I am self-taught and for the longest time I treated art as a hobby, but I'm finding that I have the desire to create art every single day and I am exploring ways to make a few dollars by selling paintings and portraits. 

This will be an important step in promoting my work as a Canadian artist - anything you can contribute will be very much appreciated... and I will be sure to keep you updated on my progress.

story:
Hello, my name is Roger Heitmann. I am a 38 year resident of Jersey City and the treasurer of the Riverview Neighborhood Association Inc. a 501(c)(3) non-profit corporation. The RNA is an all volunteer organization dedicated to a better life in the Heights since 1983.  As one of the oldest continuous neighborhood associations in Jersey City, we consider ourselves to be stewards of Riverview-Fisk Park. Our board and 200+ members are very passionate about our community and park.
We are fundraising to restore our park monuments and desperately need funding to restore the monument for Henry Hudson, famed explorer and discoverer of the Hudson river for the Dutch in 1609.
Restoration of the monument will achieve three goals. First, it will help to educate the general public about our early Dutch influenced history. Second, it will return the monument to its former glory and be a source of community pride in our park. Finally, it will draw attention to the need to restore our historic monuments all over Jersey City, which highlights the results of park beautification and may also attract commerce.
There are currently no city funds available to accomplish this task as a result of the city dedicating a majority of its spending to higher priority areas such as crime prevention and public school education.
Revitalization of our urban centers is essential to the overall health of our economy. This small project, if successful, will demonstrate what can be achieved through the teaming of local community and private support. 
We have engaged and obtained an restoration quote from a reputable firm that is in the business of restoring monuments all across the country. The bust is bronze and sits atop a solid granite pedestal.  It is currently protected from graffiti by the fence pictured. Originally created by Anton Schaaf in 1917, the bronze bust was repainted by the city with bronze paint in addition to repainting the granite pedestal in an effort to hide some graffiti done 30 years ago. 
Our contractor will remove the paint on the bust to restore it to its original patina and also remove the white paint on the granite pedestal. Then a hot wax coating will be applied to the bust to improve preservation.  The RNA and local community will be provide on-going monthly and annual maintenance of the site.
